The foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some controversy. In this paper, we provide a categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. Our approach is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear operators between categories of Hilbert spaces and modules over a suitable ring of operators. This resolves a question raised in the context of reconstruction programs.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we report the first comparative analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These findings have implications for understanding the origin and evolution of parasitic lifestyles. (Abridged)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The virus, which causes this disease, is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the nuclear import of transcription factors that are essential for the induction of antiviral genes. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of transcription factors. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that is essential for nuclear import. We also show that a simple mutation in Orf6 abolishes its ability to block nuclear import and impair the antiviral response. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used by other viruses to evade the host immune response. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of zinc inhibition of proton channels. We find that zinc binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the zinc-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how zinc inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of large yield losses. Here, we show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. This increase in variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in these countries. Our results highlight the importance of food trade and the vulnerability of the world’s poor to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet in the study of large mammal ecology and conservation. (Abridged)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly due to the selective removal of small plastic particles by food webs and ballasting processes. This finding has important implications for the understanding of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. We determined the age of a large number of presolar grains in the Murchison meteorite. The grains have been exposed to interstellar space and condensed in the protoplanetary disk. We find that the grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the solar system 4.6 Ga ago. This is in agreement with the age of the solar system.

The expansion of the global fishing fleet has been driven by the development of the motorized sector, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. However, there are signs of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet is expected to double by midcentury, with the powered-artisanal fleet growing by 50% and the industrial fleet by 30%. This will challenge the sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. This study also provides a proof of concept for the use of prodrugs in the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the first line of defense against pathogens and damage. It is also the primary regulator of vascular function and the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform a variety of functions. This paper describes the nature of the communication system between these cells and the properties of the network that they form. The network is found to be small-world, which means that it is both efficient at local and global communication. This is an important discovery for the endothelium and for vascular biology in general.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API can be used to track COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is available at https://covidcast.org/api. We hope that the API will be useful to researchers, policy makers, and the public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes, such as muscle contraction, heart rate, and blood pressure. In addition, they are the target of a large number of drugs. In this work, we have identified a key residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. We have also demonstrated that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter and opens the door for the development of new drugs.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential for the microbiome to produce bioactive compounds is just beginning to be explored. Here, we report the discovery of a diverse set of natural products produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gastrointestinal tracts of herbivores. These findings support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are a source of bioactive compounds that could be used to treat human diseases.

Social dominance is a key feature of social groups and is associated with a variety of health problems. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is known to influence social behavior, directly influences social dominance in rats and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens. We further show that the low energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and that this is associated with a low probability to become dominant. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we use a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design mechanical structures with desired responses. It also opens up new avenues for the design of complex mechanical systems with programmable responses. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein in red blood cells. The expression of hemoglobin is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and RNA-binding proteins. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, which binds to insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. In the fetal liver, IGF2BP1 is associated with the expression of fetal hemoglobin. In the adult bone marrow, IGF2BP1 is associated with the expression of adult hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies. This work also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. (Read more)

Cancer is a major cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of many effective therapies, cancer remains a major health problem. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We show that targeting this pathway with mTORC1 inhibition sensitizes cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation to ferroptosis, and that this combination therapy results in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that ferroptosis-inducing agents may be useful in cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the management of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type calcium channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with an increased risk of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate a store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells, which promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings may help to explain the increased risk of heart failure in patients treated with LCCBs and may lead to the development of new drug classes with a lower risk of heart failure. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral–associated birds, but the opposite occurred for older-forest–associated species. This is partly due to the loss of older forests to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP has been successful in halting the decline of early-seral forests, but the conservation of older forests is still a challenge. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. (Abridged)

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The predicted best candidate is more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. This work is a step toward the development of new antibiotics. The approach presented here can be used for the rational design of new antibiotics for other classes of antibiotics. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We also show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results for the problem of semantic segmentation of satellite images. The code for the proposed architecture is available online.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. From

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can have important effects on sleep, including a delay in the circadian clock, reduced melatonin levels, and reduced sleepiness in the evening. These effects may have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the geologic record. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the bulk sediment and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is consistent with a terrestrial origin of Os. In contrast, the YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The Os in the spherules is likely terrestrially derived.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is not only in the early stages of the disease but also in the maintenance of the disease.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles, which resulted in a Mesozoic diversification of specialized herbivores. These herbivores were enabled by the acquisition of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls, which may have been key to the evolution of the group.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to popular belief, larger populations do not enhance CCE. Instead, we find that the size of the population is inversely related to CCE, and that this relationship is due to the greater variation participants have access to in the larger populations. Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. This work has implications for the design of experiments, the study of cumulative cultural evolution, and the evolution of technology in general. (Abridged)

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is the strongest risk factor for AD, but the mechanism of this effect is not known. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly phagocytic. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. These studies suggest that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that APOE4 increases the accumulation of complement component C1q in the brain. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,700 km in diameter and 1,300 km in radius. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3, which is 13–15 times that of water. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. In this study, we found that the bcc phase of iron is more likely to nucleate than the hcp phase, which is the stable phase of iron at high temperatures. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. (Abridged)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are key features of marijuana abuse.

Language is the defining feature of modern humans. Yet, despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language processing are poorly understood. Here, we show that deep learning models that optimize for prediction perform well on a task of higher-level language processing (i.e., predicting the next word in a sentence). We find that these models’ neural representations and behavior are strongly correlated, suggesting that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s mechanisms of language comprehension. These results provide computationally explicit evidence for the importance of predictive processing in the human brain. They also have implications for neuroscience, machine learning, and artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. In this paper, we show that this instability is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are not stable. We introduce a new algorithm, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we prove are stable and numerically verify are effective. We also introduce a theory of stability for neural networks, which we use to prove that the FIRENET algorithm is the only one that can compute stable neural networks with a given accuracy. Our results have implications for scientific computing, where the use of neural networks is growing rapidly.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a textbook example of the failure of social distancing. In this paper, we show that this is not a new phenomenon. In 1975, a classic experiment by the psychologist Daniel Wegner was published, which was later cited as evidence for the failure of people to understand exponential growth. We show that the experiment’s design was flawed from the start, and that the conclusion is based on a misunderstanding of the experiment’s results. We also show that the experiment’s findings are not unique to this particular study, but rather a general phenomenon in psychology. Finally, we discuss the implications of this paper for the scientific community and society at large.

Leprosy is a disease that has been known for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nerves, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is the first genome sequence of a leprosy bacterium. We also show that the two leprosy bacteria are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of leprosy and the origin of the human genome. (Read more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related, as revealed by the study of quantum quenches. However, the dynamics of entanglement is a very difficult problem, as it requires the knowledge of the long-time steady state, which is not known in general. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work opens the door to the study of entanglement dynamics in a wide class of interacting systems.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is the one developed by COVI-VAC. We show that the vaccine is safe and effective in hamsters, a relevant animal model for COVID-19. The vaccine is highly attenuated, which is important for safety, and it can be produced in large quantities. The vaccine is also temperature sensitive, which is important for ease of storage and transport. These properties make COVI-VAC a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague in Europe is poorly understood. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the history of plague. Our results have implications for the control of plague, as well as for the history of vector-borne diseases in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is the organ that makes animals unique. It is the source of their intelligence and the basis of their behavior. The brain is also the most complex organ in the body. It is made of cells, and the number of cells in the brain is the number of cells that make the brain unique. This study shows that the brain is not the organ that makes animals unique. It is the number of cells in the brain that makes animals unique.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic basis for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and suggests that targeting of TRAP1 may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell morphogenesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF/cofilin action is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the mechanical state of the actin filament network, which is known to be critical for ADF/cofilin action, strongly influences the ADF/cofilin reaction. We propose that this observation is critical for the function of ADF/cofilin in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose, a common sweetener found in many other foods and beverages. This study provides evidence that the ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for developing strategies to reduce the consumption of fructose. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. Here, we use a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent settlement of Madagascar. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar and opens new avenues for the study of the human population dynamics in the Indian Ocean. (Abridged)

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This finding has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is a critical component of the genetic code that is translated into proteins. In addition to the sequence of the mRNA, the chemical modifications of the RNA can also influence the translation process. In this work, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA can alter the rate of translation. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This work provides insight into the role of mRNA modifications in the translation process. (Show more)

This study provides evidence that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging and well-being. It also highlights the importance of the subjective experience of life meaningfulness in the context of the aging process. The findings are discussed in the context of the role of meaning in life in the promotion of well-being and healthy aging. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of aquatic lifestyles has led to the diversification of four of the five extant orders of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results are consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. (Abridged)

The common cold is one of the most common and most disruptive diseases in the world. The virus that causes the common cold, rhinovirus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold. (Read more)

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the type IV pili of P. aeruginosa, a major surface-adhesion system, are also used as a mechanosensory system. This mechanosensory system is required for the detection of surfaces and regulates the expression of virulence factors. The pili-mediated mechanosensory system is part of a complex network of signals that regulate the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. Our findings thus support a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of pili is used as a sensor for surface attachment. This study thus provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria use pili as a mechanosensory system. This system is likely to be used by other bacteria as well. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of these chemicals on the environment is still poorly understood. We show that the majority of pesticides used in agriculture are present in surface waters at concentrations that are toxic to aquatic organisms. This is a major threat to the biodiversity of our rivers and lakes. Our results call for a worldwide reduction of the use of pesticides in agriculture and for a better understanding of the effects of these chemicals on the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the virus has spread to many animal species. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, which are the predominant cervid in North America. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and for the future of the human–deer relationship.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern. This paper examines the causes of this trend, the problems that are being created, and the solutions that are needed. We find that the industry is moving to building large dams in the developing world because of the lack of alternatives and the lack of regulation. We also find that the industry is overestimating the benefits and underestimating the costs of these dams. We propose solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques and microgliosis. Here, we show that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is the primary cause of the early immune response in AD. We demonstrate that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a source of a variety of proinflammatory factors, which are capable of activating microglia and initiating the inflammatory cascade. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD, since they suggest that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a key factor in the initiation of the AD-related immune response. This may also provide a rationale for the use of Aβ-based therapies in the treatment of AD.

The domestication of chickens is one of the most important events in human history. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. Here we present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that economic exploitation of chickens was practiced there as early as the fourth century B.C.E. This finding challenges the current view of the spread of chickens in the Mediterranean world and provides new insights into the early history of this species. Our results have important implications for the study of the domestication and spread of chickens in the ancient world. (Abridged)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet fully understood. Here we show that the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein, proceeds through distinct steps. The first step is a fast compaction of the protein into a polyglobular state. The second step is a slow formation of a native-like intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory step on the folding pathway. The intermediate is adjacent in the native protein to the sites of three previously reported destabilizing mutations. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results also suggest that the compaction step is a common step in the folding of other proteins. This step may be a target for the design of new proteins with faster folding. (Read more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for controlling the fate of 5′ ends of RNA molecules. In this work, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing this cap, RppH, has a unique substrate specificity for Np4-capped RNAs, which it uses to initiate the process of RNA degradation. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which bacteria can reprogram gene expression in response to stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a major amino acid, is a key molecule in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic agent to restore T cell function and decrease sepsis-induced immunosuppression. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass is more than twice the size of the terrestrial biomass, and we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. These findings are essential for understanding the structure and functioning of the ecosystem. View Full-Text

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, which is characterized by the fact that a system is in a critical state, and that the system’s activity is self-regulated. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including sandpiles, earthquakes, fire, avalanches, and even the human brain. In this paper, we present a model of SOC, which is a continuous model, in contrast to all known models. We also show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, which requires further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, sensors, and energy applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic and optical properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a platform for exploring the relationship between electronic and phonon structures, and the interplay between electronic and mechanical properties. This work is expected to advance the understanding of the fundamental physics of diamond and its applications. The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. However, the structural and functional characterization of peptides is often challenging due to their small size and the presence of disulfide bonds. Here, we report the solution structure of a unique antifungal peptide, NCR044, and its mode of action against plant fungal pathogens. The results of this study provide a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and pave the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, to control bleeding. In some people, mutations in VWF cause a bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF binds to platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) in a force-dependent manner, and that force can be used to activate VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the pathophysiology of VWD. The mechanism is also relevant for other proteins that bind to receptors on the cell surface.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, due to the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The database is also used to study the impact of the virome on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. This instrument is capable of providing high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We use this instrument to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that the increase of aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, which is consistent with expectations. However, the increase of aerosol loading did not lead to an increase in liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is of particular interest because it is a key factor in the evolution of life. Here, we use the thermostability of ancestral enzymes to determine the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

Ion channels commonly possess two pore gates, one for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We hypothesized that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a critical step in the disease pathogenesis. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, which may facilitate invasion. We show that the malaria parasite binds to glycophorin A on the RBC surface and that this binding leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. These changes in the RBC are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This work provides a new perspective on malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work has implications for the development of antimalarial drugs and for the design of new malaria vaccines. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, by applying a small strain. This opens up new possibilities for the control of electronic and optical properties of diamond.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the role of host defense and repair in the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus on human health. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence as a whole, from the top down, but there is no direct evidence for this. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the formation of a sentence is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is a fundamental finding for the study of sentence processing and for the development of computational models of language.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also at the level of gene regulation. We show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the pathway. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of redundant genes and may help in the understanding of the evolution of the Wnt pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, even when they are sated. We also show that this effect is blocked by lesions of the dopamine system, which is known to be involved in feeding. However, we show that the LH system is not involved in the mechanisms of hunger or satiety that govern normal feeding. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen cycle is therefore a key capability for sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial signaling system that allows the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal host. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to deliver biologically fixed nitrogen in cereal crops, thus reducing the need for synthetic nitrogen fertilizers and the associated environmental impacts. This work also represents a proof of principle for the use of transkingdom signaling in the control of microbial gene expression in a eukaryotic host. (Read more)

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. The program was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. The results from our analysis suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. The estimated reductions were largest in communities facing the largest threats. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. (Abridged)

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions. We find that the reduction of these emissions can save 3.61 million lives per year, which is about 50% of the total number of deaths from outdoor air pollution. This number is further increased to 5.55 million per year if we additionally consider the effects of nonfossil anthropogenic emissions. The model also shows that the removal of fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C of warming, which is about 20% of the total anthropogenic warming. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. COVID-19 vaccines are needed globally to contain the pandemic. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain (RBD) variant that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This variant is heterotypic against the RBD from the variants of concern and may be used to design vaccines for these variants.

Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor of the neural crest, a group of cells that give rise to a variety of tissues and organs. In the last years, we have identified mutations in the gene encoding the protooncogene anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) as a cause of neuroblastoma. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by zebrafish ALKALs. Our results provide evidence that ALKALs are ligands for ALK/LTK family receptors and that these receptors are involved in the development of the neural crest. This study provides a link between the zebrafish and human systems and opens up new avenues for the study of ALK/LTK family receptors in vivo. This article is protected by copyright. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like ancestor is one of the most important events in the history of microbiology. Here, we present 17 ancient Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of plague during this critical period. We find that the plague lineage was nonflea-adapted and that it spread across Eurasia, with a rapid expansion into Europe and the Middle East. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its adaptation to fleas. This work also highlights the importance of ancient DNA in understanding the history of pathogens. (Abridged)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. We found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. Implications for theory and practice are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record

The management of agricultural systems can affect the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. In this study, we show that the management of annual cropping systems on a Midwestern Mollisol can affect the amount of C stored in the soil. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerability of humans to viruses that spillover from animals. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 zoonotic viruses, which included SARS-CoV-2. We also created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the data and prioritize their own list of viruses of interest. SpillOver is a living database that can be updated over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. In this study, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the study of the evolution of vertebrate pollination. (Show more)

The genetic landscape of Europe is a complex mosaic of genetic contributions from different parts of the world. However, the processes that shaped this landscape are still poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 450 and 750 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic landscape of Europe was shaped by multiple waves of migration, including a major influx of genetic ancestry from eastern Europe, and that women were a major contributor to the genetic landscape of Europe. In addition, we found that many genes that are associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide new insights into the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of Europe. (Abridged)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The global pandemic of COVID-19 has highlighted the importance of rapid pathogen surveillance and response. However, in resource-scarce settings, such as Cambodia, the capacity to detect and respond to emerging pathogens is limited. Here, we describe the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a periurban population in Cambodia. Our findings highlight the importance of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can better inform public health response and preparedness. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a process that is similar to that of S. cerevisiae but with some notable differences. In particular, the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic experiments that reveal that the human pol δ holoenzyme is not as stable as its S. cerevisiae counterpart. This finding has important implications for the replication of the human genome as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. These results provide a unique perspective on the replication of the human genome and may have implications for cancer and other diseases.

The origin of life is one of the most important questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated, but the process is inefficient and requires the use of proteins. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA in a protein-free form of PCR. This ribozyme can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the development of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of cities over time and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape cities. (Abridged)

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, which has caused a large number of deaths worldwide. The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab may be a potential therapeutic strategy for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal. The existence of a fungal metal homeostasis system is well established, but the role of the system in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and in interactions with competing microbes is not. Here we demonstrate that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and the impact of copper on fungal interactions with other microbes. (Read more)

The formation of silica-rich minerals in a sedimentary environment is a rare occurrence in the solar system. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock is consistent with the formation of silica in a high-temperature, high-pressure environment. The diagenesis of the sedimentary rock is consistent with the presence of a variety of aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. Frost damage is a major threat to the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts and the resistance strategies of trees to frost damage are closely linked. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. Here we show that the development of colitis requires the dual action of Th17 cells, which can directly induce the development of Th1-like cells and provide help for the development of pathogenic Th1 cells. These results have implications for the development of novel therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and by toxic effects of misfolded proteins in other cell types. Here we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to test potential therapies. This method will enable the rapid production of large numbers of cells for disease modeling and drug screening. It will also allow the study of the effects of genetic and environmental factors on disease progression. This will be of great importance for the development of personalized therapies. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the ability of the pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum to colonize the vector. We now show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the tick gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance colonization. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The discovery of a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the avian tail. The discovery of this group of birds also highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of mosaic characters.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the atmosphere. In this paper, we show that the atmosphere plays a significant role in the evolution of our climate.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. However, some vertebrates, such as frogs, have green tissues due to the presence of biliverdin, a pigment that is not naturally present in the body. We show that this green color is the result of a mechanism that has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of frogs. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most diverse group of protease inhibitors.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is enriched in cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human ACE2 receptor, and we show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has little effect on the structure of the protein. However, we find that the D614G mutant spike is more flexible and can adopt a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein and may help to inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
