COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and physics. In particular, the chemical potential of an electron is a key parameter in chemistry, and the chemical hardness is a key parameter in physics. Here, we show that the chemical potential of an electron and the chemical hardness of an atom decrease with pressure, and we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure.

Fire is a key natural process in terrestrial ecosystems, but its role in the climate system is complex and poorly understood. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can have a large effect on the future fire regime, which in turn can affect the climate. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to consider the role of human ignitions in future projections. This study also highlights the importance of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon in the Earth system. Our study provides a framework for understanding the role of fire in the climate system and for quantifying the uncertainty in future projections. (Abridged)

The gut microbiota is a critical component of the health of many animals, but the mechanisms by which they interact are poorly understood. Here, we show that the symbiotic bacterium of the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates its own population in the crypts of the host organ, which are used for bioluminescence, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the pH of the crypts to enhance its own metabolism. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the gut microbiota, which may be common in other animal hosts. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but the patterns they encode are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We apply this method to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to any domain, and it can be extended to other types of data. We hope it will be useful to researchers and practitioners.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This study shows that the bacterium was repeatedly reintroduced into Europe from Asia, via the ancient Silk Road, over this period. This finding challenges the prevailing view that the bacterium was established in Europe for the first time in 1347. Instead, we find that the bacterium was already present in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe, and that it was reintroduced into Europe on multiple occasions over the course of the second plague pandemic. This study thus provides evidence for a complex history of the introduction of plague into Europe, which is likely to have had important consequences for the spread of the disease in the continent. (Abridged)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of coastal ecosystems. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that leads to rapid mortality. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus and that it is transmitted by the sea star. This study provides evidence that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the sea star. The findings have important implications for the management of this important ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that a monoclonal antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is effective in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that the observed effects are mediated by effector-cell–mediated cytotoxicity and that natural killer cells are critical for the observed therapeutic effects. Furthermore, we show that the antibody can also inhibit the proliferation of primary AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Thus, our results may lead to the development of a new treatment for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the human history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework for the study of the human history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This work provides insight into the role of small RNAs in the regulation of metabolism. It also demonstrates the importance of the translation function of small RNAs. Finally, it provides a model for how base pairing functions. This work also

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus not amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert network is a valuable source of information that can be used to improve agricultural monitoring and forecasting systems.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during the course of learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Abridged)

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life. It is also one of the most challenging questions in biology, as it is difficult to study in the laboratory. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key event in the evolution of life, is also a major evolutionary challenge. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The Day Zero drought in Cape Town in 2018 was the result of a prolonged rainfall deficit. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of such a drought by a factor of five to six in the past decade. This probability will increase to 25 to 80% by the year 2100 under intermediate- and high-emission scenarios, respectively. This result highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also show that the drought risk in SSA is highly sensitive to the spatial distribution of rainfall, which is not well represented in current climate models. This highlights the need for improved regional climate models and the development of drought indices that can be used to assess the drought risk in SSA. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the study of materials. However, the conditions under which they form are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the synthesis of quasicrystals in the laboratory. It also provides a link between the discovery of a new quasicrystal and the discovery of a new material. This discovery has implications for the study of quasicrystals and for the search for new materials. (Abridged)

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction is unknown, and the only known enzymes are two unrelated proteins. Here we show that the two enzymes are related, and that they are required for oxygenic photosynthesis.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. Neuroinflammation is known to be regulated by mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of neuroinflammation in EAE. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the development of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes may be potential therapeutic targets for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may provide a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in the development of neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by the effects of multiple genes and environmental factors. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a molecular mechanism for autism and suggest that the activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting is a therapeutic target for autism. This study also provides a framework for the identification of the converging functions of autism-risk genes. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the prevalence of negativity biases in the world’s news content. It finds that, on average, news content is overwhelmingly negative. It also finds that, on average, individuals are more responsive to negative than positive information. These findings have important implications for the study of human cognition and behavior, and for the design of news content.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of ORAI1, which result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Read more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in Drosophila is dependent on the presence of a defined subset of neurons, the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous, and the release of aggregates is dependent on fusion protein 1. These findings provide a model for the spread of aggregates in the brain and suggest that the release of aggregates is a potential therapeutic target in neurodegenerative diseases. This work also provides a platform for the study of the spread of aggregates in other diseases, including Huntington’s disease. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are still poorly understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein, named MTX, inhibits the antiviral immune response and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Our findings may help to develop new strategies for the prevention and control of viral diseases in bats and humans. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a rescue for SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of this cancer. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the coaggregating proteins have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This work provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that the 2D photonic crystal system is a promising platform for a wide range of experiments in quantum simulation and quantum engineering. The Cretaceous period is often considered to be the age of dinosaurs. However, the fossil record shows that the first flowering plants appeared in the fossil record more than 120 million y ago. The study of Montsechia, a Cretaceous aquatic angiosperm, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

Parvoviruses are small, circular, double-stranded DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature and cause a number of diseases in humans. The most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is estimated to have existed ∼12.6 kya, and the most common parvovirus, genotype 1, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 kya. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Abridged)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This acceleration is a result of a combination of natural and anthropogenic processes. We find that the rate of rise is increasing, and that the acceleration is primarily due to the anthropogenic increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader pattern of decline in the quality of life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the fate of the leaving group in a reaction catalyzed by a tryptophan synthase. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the active site, including the location of key hydrogen bonds and the orientation of water molecules. This study also demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in providing mechanistic insight into the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. Finally, this study demonstrates the ability of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide insight into the role of a substrate isostere in the mechanism of an enzyme. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. The continued emergence of MERS cases with a high case fatality rate stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a promising drug that has been shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection prevented and treated the disease, respectively. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota is a critical component of the health of many animals, but the mechanisms by which they interact are poorly understood. Here, we show that the symbiotic bacterium of the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates its own population in the crypts of the host organ, which is used for bioluminescence, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the pH of the habitat, enhancing the capacity of the symbiont to produce bioluminescence at night. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbes in animals. (Show more)

This study has implications for the future of education. It shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved, and suspension rates reduced, through a simple, scalable intervention. This intervention is based on the idea that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This mindset is associated with better relationships and lower suspension rates. The intervention is scalable because it can be delivered online, and because it requires no change in the law. DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is involved in the etiology of cancer and other diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct pol II stalling profiles. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will help to understand the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. In the UK, the food system is responsible for 10–15% of greenhouse gas emissions, and the food we eat is the second largest contributor to the UK’s land use footprint. In the US, the food system is responsible for 20–30% of greenhouse gas emissions and 10–20% of freshwater use. The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the cell surface proteome is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry and activated ion electron transfer dissociation to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most common oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal electoral consequences. This is an important contribution to the literature on the effects of voting rules and election administration.

SARS-CoV-2 is a rapidly evolving virus that has caused a global pandemic. The role of the ORF8 protein in the virus’s pathogenesis is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 at 2.04-Å resolution. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion and virus persistence. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of SARS-CoV-2 pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common feature of the brain, and it is known to trigger the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. Here we show that hypoxia triggers the release of CRF from the hypothalamus, which acts on CRF receptors (CRFR1) in the cortex to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanism for the development of edema in hypoxia, which may be relevant to the development of edema in other conditions, such as brain trauma. It also provides a potential target for the treatment of edema. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe a number of recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The key idea is that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This is a fundamental challenge in the analysis of complex datasets.

The development of vascular endothelium is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. Here, we report the discovery of a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2), that directly induces the formation of vascular endothelium from nonvascular cells. This discovery provides a new approach for the generation of vascular endothelium and the regeneration of vascular networks. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 may be applicable to the treatment of vascular disorders. These findings may lead to the development of new therapies for vascular diseases. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK has opened up a new field of research in the field of RTKs. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a unique type of dermal chromatophores in the zebrafish. Our results establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a new perspective on the role of RTKs in the development of the skin. (Show more)

β-Cell dysfunction is one of the main molecular bases for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Herein, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to defective insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. STING deficiency in β-cells also led to down-regulation of Pax6, which is a transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging process. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction resulted in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. The interaction we identified involves regions not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A virus. This study provides insights into the molecular details of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are the result of a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we focus on the role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that disturbed flow activates YAP/TAZ in cultured endothelial cells and in mouse arteries. YAP/TAZ activation promotes the development of atheroprone phenotypes, including proliferation and inflammation. In addition, statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibits YAP/TAZ activities and reduces the size of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate a critical role of the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow in promoting atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides insights into the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. These findings may help to develop new therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. (Abridged)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change. We hope that our method will be useful to urban researchers and practitioners.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median VL by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median VL by ∼2 d

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their zooxanthellate symbionts and turn white. This breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a major threat to coral reefs worldwide. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. In the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. This feedback loop is essential for tumor growth and organismal lifespan extension. Our work identifies a mechanism that can be targeted to control tumor growth and to restore homeostasis in the intestinal epithelium. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the interplay between tumors, the microbiome, and the intestinal epithelium, and it has implications for cancer therapy and for the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis in health and disease. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond well to treatment. In this study, we show that the expression of the ROR1 receptor is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression is associated with the expression of genes that are induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). We also show that the expression of ROR1 is associated with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reestablish tumorigenicity in mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer.

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is linked to a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes similar to those observed today.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that most catches come from rivers with high stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poor and undernourished. This analysis highlights the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need to protect these ecosystems from overfishing and other threats. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate neurons is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate in response to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery has implications for the study of regeneration in the mammalian CNS and for the development of therapies to restore neuronal function in the adult brain.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, which are interspersed with cold regions. The distribution of hotspots is similar to that observed in yeast and in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This work provides a foundation for understanding the distribution of recombination in plants, which are the most diverse group of organisms on Earth. It also provides a model for studying the evolution of recombination in a flowering plant.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to reflect the structure of the underlying neuronal connectivity. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the brain is also highly structured, and that this organization is similar to the functional organization. This finding has important implications for the study of the brain in health and disease, as it allows the use of metabolic imaging to identify and validate the functional organization of the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is a well-known modification of messenger RNA (mRNA) that is essential for efficient translation. In bacteria, the 5′ NAD+ cap is also important for translation, but its function in eukaryotes is unknown. We show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. We also show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is not a product of 5′ processing, but is instead produced cotranscriptionally. This discovery expands the number of 5′ modifications in eukaryotes and raises the possibility that the 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery also provides a foundation for future studies of the function of 5′ NAD+ cap in yeast and other eukaryotes. (Read more)

Metabolic memory is the beneficial effect of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that DNA methylation of certain loci in blood cells is altered during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and persists for several years during the long-term follow-up of the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These loci are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the maintenance of the metabolic memory. Our results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This work may also have implications for the study of other diseases with a long-term follow-up. (Read more)

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease, which is characterized by a high mortality rate. The aim of the present study was to explore the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in the flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor, 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. This pathway provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in plants and opens the door to the development of improved tomato cultivars with enhanced flavor. (Read more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are not simply additive to the impacts of biodiversity loss. Instead, we find that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is altered by changes in temperature. This finding is driven by two processes: (i) more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress, and (ii) the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increases at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of climate change on the thermal tolerance traits of species, as well as the species interactions that mediate the impacts of biodiversity loss, in order to understand the full extent of the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning. This is important for understanding the impacts of climate change on the functioning of ecosystems and the services they provide.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains two subregions, the superficial MEC (sMEC) and the parasubiculum, which are thought to have different functions. Here, we show that the sMEC contains two types of neurons, grid cells and non-grid cells, which are anatomically segregated and functionally distinct. This finding has implications for understanding the organization of the sMEC and its role in navigation.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-containing nigro–striato–nigral loop. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized subsystem of this loop, the striosome–dendron bouquet, which is likely to be affected in the disease. The bouquet is a highly specialized unit within the dopamine-containing system that is likely to be critical to the control of movement and motivation.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate, and their automaticity is governed by a complex network of electrical and Ca2+ signaling. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ signaling in SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, and that this effect is mediated by an increase in Si and JA levels and by priming of defense responses. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the metabolism of other lipids, including ceramides and cardiolipins, which have no direct connection to ether lipid pathways. Our results demonstrate a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This study provides a new perspective on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and opens new avenues for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during the course of learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the primary producers of the biosphere and are the primary targets of biomolecules in the environment. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures, which are able to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will help in the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and beyond.

Eutrophication is one of the greatest threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of the nutrients entering lakes and rivers come from nonpoint sources, such as agricultural fields and urban areas. However, the role of small streams in delivering nutrients to the coast is largely unknown. We show that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to the nearshore zone of large lakes. Our findings have important implications for coastal management, as they suggest that small streams may be a major source of coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to a small fraction of the possible chemical configurations. We find that the system is biased toward configurations that extremize the environmental forcing. We show that this bias is a consequence of the network’s topology and the environment’s dynamics. Our results suggest that the extremization of environmental forcing may be a general principle that can be used to design robust, robust, and efficient chemical networks.

This study offers a mechanistic explanation for the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with an autoimmune encephalitis caused by a dysfunction of the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor. The study also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of dysfunction of the NMDA receptor, which is a target for many drugs used to treat neurological disorders.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth science. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and that the warming was driven by an increase in nutrient availability. This study provides insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the potential for future climate change. (Abridged)

Palm oil is the most widely produced vegetable oil in the world, and its production is expanding rapidly in tropical forests. In response, many companies and countries have made commitments to purchase only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. (Abridged)

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In plants, the exocyst complex is involved in the regulation of vacuolar trafficking. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex in plants is still unknown. Here, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In many species, the sex of an individual is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on the secondary sexual characteristics of a fish, the cichlid Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the multiple alleles of sex determination in this species produce a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics, which can be further modified by the acquisition of a new sex determination allele. These results provide insight into the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in vertebrates. (Abridged)

The retina is a unique organ in that it is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by the photoreceptors and the retinal pigment epithelium, respectively. The photoreceptors are also challenged by the accumulation of lipofuscin, a complex of oxidized proteins and lipids. We show that the level of iron in the retina impacts the balance between these two sources of ROS. In the presence of light, iron promotes the oxidation and degradation of the lipofuscin precursor A2E. This work provides insight into the role of iron in the retina and may lead to the development of therapeutic strategies to protect the retina from damage. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key factor in the functioning of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of the feeding strategy of siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, has been linked to the evolution of their tentacles. Our results show that the evolution of siphonophore tentacles has been linked to the evolution of their prey, and that these tentacles have been adapted to capture different prey types. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides evidence for the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a rescue for SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of this cancer. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. (Read more)

The world is experiencing a nutrition crisis, with an estimated 829 million people suffering from undernourishment. In low- and middle-income countries, the majority of undernourished people live in rural areas, where agriculture is the main source of income. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by having access to natural landscapes such as forests. This study has important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets and livelihoods. It also has implications for conservationists, who should consider the role of deforestation in people’s diets and the potential for “win–wins” in terms of conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods in nutrition research. (Abridged)

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it comes at a cost to the environment. In particular, the use of farm machinery has led to the compaction of the soil, which reduces its capacity to absorb water and nutrients and to store carbon. This study shows that the use of farm machinery has led to the compaction of the subsoil, which is now at risk of irreversible damage. The results of this study have important implications for the design of farm machinery, which should be made lighter to reduce the risk of subsoil compaction. This could lead to a more sustainable agriculture, with fewer negative impacts on the environment.
